awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: The Evolutionary Ecology of Seed Mucilage in Plantago Species
awd_abstract_narration:
As the globe is warming and rainfall is less predictable, it is important to determine the traits that allow plants to cope with increased water stress. Some seeds can produce a gelatinous covering many times the size of the seed that expands when the seed gets wet. This functional trait, known as mucilage, may be an important way plants deal with stressful environments--for instance, by increasing seed germination percentage and seedling establishment in conditions of water stress--yet little is known about the trait This study will compare seeds from Plantago lanceolata, known as common plantain, that experience different habitat across the globe.  The researcher will determine the frequency of this trait in dry habitats, its effect on seed germination, plant growth, and plant success under low and unpredictable water availability. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Zhenying Huang, an expert on seed mucilage at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing and the Central Mongolian Field Station.

Seed mucilage (myxospermy) is found in 230 genera of angiosperms and has been demonstrated to serve a variety of ecological functions including aid in dispersal and germination.  There is a trade-off between seed number per fruit and mucilage in P. coronopus along a latitudinal gradient, suggesting that seed mucilage may be costly to produce and mitigate stressful environments (increased temperature and reduced precipitation). The researcher will use a common garden experiment to conduct an intraspecific study on myxospermy in P. lanceolata, a perennial species with a global distribution.  The researcher will ask if seed mucilage increases germination and establishment of P. lanceolata under low and high osmotic stress. Through comparison of spatially dispersed populations, the researcher will determine whether seed mucilage production differs along a temperature or precipitation gradient. The researcher predicts that the seed to mucilage ratio will be greater in arid and highly stochastic environments where buffering may be needed. Another prediction is that seed mucilage will improve fitness when seeds are exposed to osmotic stress. 

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

por.por_cntn:
Working with my EAPSI host, Dr. Zhenying Huang, at the Institute of Botany of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, China, I developed methods and learned skills to investigate seed mucilage as an important trait for germination. Seed mucilage is a part of the seed coat in Plantago lanceolata (narrowleaf plantain) that expands when the seed is exposed to water. This polysaccharide layer expands up to 60-fold to cover the seed in a sticky envelope (example: chia seeds have seed mucilage). Seed mucilage is found in hundreds of plant species across the phylogeny of flowering plants, and yet very little is known about the ecological functions of this trait. Previous studies have shown that plant mucilage can be important for increasing germination in arid environments, protecting DNA from intense sunlight, and may be important for dispersal via water (it changes the buoyancy of the seeds, allowing them to float) or by attaching to animals or the soil surface (preventing seeds from being carried off by ants). With Dr. Huang, I developed research questions to compare 1) the effects of seed mucilage on the germination percentage of narrowleaf plantain and 2) the variability in the amount of seed mucilage produced by populations of narrowleaf plantain from different regions of the globe (that experience different climates). I hypothesized that seed mucilage would increase germination percentages and that populations that are under more drought stress would have more seed mucilage.

The broader purpose of this study is to understand what traits and environmental cues are important in triggering germination of seeds. As environmental conditions change, it is even more important to understand the conditions needed for seeds to germinate and how this varies with the traits of the seeds. Understanding germination cues is valuable to the maintenance of diversity and in selecting appropriate crops and seed sources.

During the EAPSI program, I worked with Dr. Huang and Dr. Yang to learn how to handle mucilaginous seeds and how to carefully remove the mucilage completely without damaging the seed. I developed methods for consistently measuring the amount of seed mucilage and I completed a pilot germination experiment to compare the germination percentages of seeds with and without mucilage under various levels of water stress. Preliminary results support my first hypothesis as seeds with mucilage were able to maintain high germination percentages even when water stressed. Additionally, I was able to collect seeds from 9 different populations of plantain species to be used for comparison in a larger germination experiment scheduled to be completed this year.

The EAPSI program provided me the opportunity to learn the value of international collaborations. This program allowed me to create ties with Dr. Zhenying’s laboratory group and engage in discussions about culture and science with students and professors. This experience taught me that scientists are open to collaborating and that you do not have to share the same culture to work together productively. I am grateful for my time as a visiting student in Dr. Zhenying’s laboratory as I learned about seed ecology and developed skills for studying seeds that I will use during my PhD research. Continuation of this collaboration will further knowledge of seed mucilage and its ecological role in germination.
